docs.title: Welcome to RemoteGazeUX 👁️
docs.text: The Future of Remote UX Research is Here. RemoteGazeUX transforms how you understand user behavior. Run professional eye-tracking studies from anywhere in the world — no lab, no expensive equipment, no installation required.

docs.title: 🚀 Why RemoteGazeUX?
docs.text:
Traditional eye-tracking studies require expensive hardware, dedicated lab spaces, and participants to be physically present. Not anymore.

RemoteGazeUX brings the power of professional eye-tracking research to your browser:

  • 💰 Zero Hardware Costs - Just a webcam
  • 🌍 Global Reach - Test users anywhere in the world
  • ⚡ Instant Setup - From download to first study in 5 minutes
  • 📊 Professional Results - Publication-ready heatmaps and data
  • 🔓 Open Source - Customize everything to your needs

docs.title: 🎯 Perfect For
docs.text:
UX ResearchersProduct TeamsAcademic ResearchersDesign Agencies

Validate your designs with real eye-tracking data. See exactly where users look, what they miss, and how they navigate your prototypes.

Make data-driven decisions about interface design. No more guessing — know precisely what captures attention.

Conduct rigorous HCI studies with reproducible methodology. Export raw data for statistical analysis.

Wow your clients with eye-tracking insights. Show them exactly how users experience their designs.

docs.title: 👁️ Webcam-Based Eye Tracking
docs.text: Powered by WebGazer.js, the gold standard in browser-based eye tracking. Research-grade accuracy without the research-grade price tag.

docs.title: 🖱️ Mouse Tracking Included
docs.text: Capture the complete interaction story. See not just where users look, but where they click, scroll, and hover.

docs.title: 🎨 Your Prototypes, Your Way
docs.text: Test Figma designs, live websites, static images, or custom interfaces. If it's on the web, you can track it.

docs.title: 📈 Beautiful Visualizations
docs.text: Generate stunning heatmaps and gaze plots automatically. Download publication-ready visuals or raw CSV data.

docs.title: 🔐 Privacy First
docs.text: Self-hosted solution means you control all data. Perfect for sensitive projects and GDPR compliance.

docs.title: 🛠️ Researcher-Friendly
docs.text: Designed by researchers, for researchers. Task-based studies, custom forms, multi-study management — everything you need is built in.

docs.title: 🎬 See It In Action
docs.text:
Ready to transform your UX research? Here's what you can do:

  1. 📝 Create a Study - Define your tasks and upload your prototype
  2. 👥 Invite Participants - Share a simple link (no installation needed)
  3. 📊 Collect Data - Automatic calibration, tracking, and storage
  4. 🔍 Analyze Results - Interactive heatmaps, gaze plots, and CSV exports

docs.title: 🏁 Quick Start
docs.text:
# Clone and run - it's that simple
git clone https://github.com/justogm/RemoteGazeUX.git
cd RemoteGazeUX
python run.py

In less than 5 minutes, you'll have a professional eye-tracking platform running locally.

Get Started → See Features →

docs.title: 📚 Tech Stack
docs.text:
Built on battle-tested technologies:

  • Flask - Robust Python web framework
  • WebGazer.js - Proven eye-tracking algorithm (cited in 1000+ papers)
  • heatmap.js - Beautiful, interactive visualizations
  • SQLite - Reliable, zero-config database

docs.title: 🤝 Join the Community
docs.text:
RemoteGazeUX is more than software — it's a community of researchers and designers democratizing UX research.

  • ⭐ Star us on GitHub
  • 🐛 Report issues
  • 💡 Suggest features

docs.title: 📖 Citation
docs.text:
Soon...

Ready to see where your users really look? Get Started in 5 Minutes →

docs.title: Configuration Guide
docs.text:
Customize Everything

RemoteGazeUX is designed to adapt to YOUR research needs. This guide shows you how to make it yours.

docs.title: 🎛️ Configuration Methods
docs.text:
You have two ways to configure RemoteGazeUX:

🖥️ GUI (Recommended)📝 JSON Files

Visual, friendly, no-code solution

You can open it when asked to modify the configuration with 

python run.py

Or with:

python src/config.py

Perfect for:

  • Quick changes
  • Non-technical team members
  • Visual learners
  • Initial setup

Direct file editing for power users

Edit: src/config/config.json and src/config/tasks.json

Perfect for:

  • Version control
  • Scripted deployments
  • Batch changes
  • Advanced users

Choose whatever works best for you! Both methods achieve the same result.

docs.title: Study Settings
docs.text:
Configure the basics of your study:

{
    "url_path": "https://google.com",
    "img_path": "null",
    "port": "5001"
}

Available Options:

Setting Description Example url_path URL to a prototipe "https://google.com" img_path Path to a static image "/home/admin/example_image.png" port In which port it should run 8000

Multiple Prototype Types

Figma Prototype: 

{
  "url_path": "https://www.figma.com/proto/abc123/MyDesign",
  "img_path": "null"
}

Static Image: 

{
  "url_path": "null",
  "img_path": "/home/admin/example_image.png"
}

Live Website: 

{
  "url_path": "https://your-staging-site.com",
  "img_path": "null"
}

docs.title: 📋 Task Configuration
docs.text: Define tasks for your participants:

docs.title: Simple Tasks
docs.text:
Edit src/config/tasks.json:

[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "description": "Find the login button",
    "duration": 30,
    "required": true
  },
  {
    "id": 2,
    "description": "Locate the pricing information",
    "duration": 45,
    "required": true
  },
  {
    "id": 3,
    "description": "Explore the features section",
    "duration": 60,
    "required": false
  }
]

Task Properties:

Property Type Description id Number Unique identifier description String What participants should do duration Number Time limit in seconds required Boolean Must complete to proceed

docs.title: Advanced Task Features
docs.text:
Add complexity for sophisticated studies:

{
  "id": 1,
  "description": "Find and click the 'Contact Us' button",
  "duration": 45,
  "required": true,
  "target_element": "button#contact",
  "success_criteria": {
    "type": "click",
    "element": "button#contact",
    "auto_advance": true
  },
  "hints": {
    "30": "The button is usually in the header or footer",
    "40": "Look at the top-right corner"
  }
}

Task Ideas

E-commerce:

  • "Add the blue shirt to your cart"
  • "Find products under $50"
  • "Navigate to customer reviews"

SaaS Platform:

  • "Create a new project"
  • "Find the pricing page"
  • "Locate the help documentation"

Information Site:

  • "Find the contact information"
  • "Locate the hours of operation"
  • "Navigate to the about page"

docs.title: Using the GUI
docs.text:
1. Open config GUI: python src/config.py
  2. Make your changes
  3. Click Save
  4. Restart the application: python run.py

docs.title: Editing JSON Directly
docs.text:
1. Edit src/config/config.json and/or src/config/tasks.json
  2. Save the files
  3. Restart: python run.py

Validation

Invalid JSON will prevent the application from starting. Use a JSON validator!s

docs.title: 🆘 Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Configuration not loading?

  • Check JSON syntax (no trailing commas!)
  • Ensure required fields are present
  • Check file permissions

Tasks not appearing?

  • Verify tasks.json is valid JSON
  • Ensure task IDs are unique
  • Check task required field

Prototype not loading?

  • Verify URL is accessible
  • Check prototype type matches URL
  • Ensure CORS settings allow embedding

Ready to run your configured study? → Quick Start Guide

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text:
You'll be up and running in under 5 minutes!

RemoteGazeUX is designed for simplicity. No complex setup, no configuration headaches.

docs.title: 📋 Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have:

  • Python 3.8 or higher (Download Python)
  • Git (optional, but recommended) (Download Git)
  • A webcam (built-in or external)
  • A modern browser (Chrome, Firefox, or Edge)

That's it! No expensive hardware, no special equipment.

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Installation
docs.text:
Method 1: Git Clone (Recommended)Method 2: Download ZIP

The fastest way to get started:

# 1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/justogm/RemoteGazeUX.git

# 2. Navigate to the folder
cd RemoteGazeUX

# 3. Run the application
python run.py

That's all! 🎉 The script will:

  • ✅ Automatically install all dependencies
  • ✅ Set up the database
  • ✅ Walk you through initial configuration
  • ✅ Start the web server

Prefer not to use Git? No problem:

  1. Download: Go to the repository page
  2. Extract: Click the green "Code" button → "Download ZIP"
  3. Unzip: Extract the ZIP file to your preferred location
  4. Run: Open a terminal in the extracted folder and run:
python run.py

docs.title: 🎯 First Run Setup
docs.text: When you run python run.py for the first time, you'll see an interactive setup wizard:

docs.title: Step 1: Create Admin Account
docs.text:
🔐 Current users in database: 0
Do you want to create a new user? (y/n): y

============================================================
👥 CREATE NEW USER
============================================================

Username: admin
Password: 
Confirm password: 

✅ User 'admin' created successfully!
============================================================

Keep these credentials safe!

You'll need them to access participant data and results.

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Your Study
docs.text:
When the application detects that you set in the configuration an url that wasn't present in the database it will allow you to set a name and a description.

============================================================
📊 New configuration detected!
============================================================
Prototype URL: https://google.com

Enter a name for this study (or press Enter for auto-name): Google Sudy
Enter a description (optional): Study of Google UX
✅ Created new study: 'Google Sudy' (ID: 1)
============================================================

docs.title: ✅ Verify Installation
docs.text:
Open your browser and navigate to the url shown at the end of the print. You should see the participant registration page!

Installation Complete! 🎉

You're ready to run your first eye-tracking study!

docs.title: Port Already in Use?
docs.text: If port is busy, you can change it with the configuration at the start of the run.

docs.title: Python Not Found?
docs.text:
Make sure Python is in your PATH. Try:

python3 run.py  # On macOS/Linux
py run.py       # On Windows

docs.title: Permission Errors?
docs.text:
On Linux/macOS, you might need:

chmod +x run.py

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• 🐛 Open an issue
  • 💬 Ask the community

docs.title: 🎓 Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you're up and running:

  1. 📚 Learn about configuring studies
  2. 👀 Explore the features
  3. 🎯 Run your first study

Ready to start tracking? → Quick Start Guide

docs.title: Features Overview
docs.text:
Everything You Need for Professional Eye-Tracking Research

RemoteGazeUX packs enterprise-level features into an easy-to-use, open-source package.

docs.title: 👁️ Webcam-Based Eye Tracking
docs.text:
No hardware required. Just a standard webcam.

  • WebGazer.js Integration - Research-grade eye tracking in the browser
  • Automatic Calibration - Smart calibration process guides participants
  • Cross-browser Support - Works in Chrome, Firefox, and Edge

Proven Accuracy

WebGazer.js has been validated in hundreds of research studies. Typical accuracy: 50-100 pixels under good conditions.

docs.title: 🖱️ Mouse Tracking
docs.text:
Complete interaction picture. Track every click, move, and scroll.

  • Movement Tracking - Full mouse path recording
  • Synchronized Data - Mouse and gaze data perfectly aligned

docs.title: 📊 Powerful Data Collection
docs.text:
Professional-grade data storage and export.

  • SQLite Database - Fast, reliable, zero-configuration
  • Automatic Timestamps - Every data point time-stamped
  • Task Segmentation - Data organized by task
  • CSV Export - Analysis-ready data files
  • Batch Downloads - Export entire studies at once

docs.title: 🎨 Flexible Prototype Support
docs.text:
Test anything that runs in a browser.

Live WebsitesFigma PrototypesStatic Images

Real-World Testing

  • Test production sites
  • Staging environments
  • Any URL
  • Full interactivity

Perfect for: Website redesigns, usability audits

Most Popular Choice

  • Direct Figma embed support
  • Interactive prototypes
  • Real user flows
  • No technical setup

Perfect for: UX designers, product teams

Simple and Fast

  • Upload any image
  • PNG, JPG, SVG support
  • Quick A/B testing
  • No prototype needed

Perfect for: Visual design testing, mockup validation

docs.title: 📋 Task-Based Studies
docs.text:
Structure your research with clear tasks:

  • Multiple Tasks - Define sequential or parallel tasks
  • Task Instructions - Clear guidance for participants
  • Success Tracking - Detect task completion automatically
  • Skip Logic - Conditional task flows

docs.title: 📈 Beautiful Visualizations
docs.text: Publication-ready graphics, automatically generated.

docs.title: Heatmaps
docs.text:
See attention patterns at a glance:

  • Color-coded intensity - Red = high attention, blue = low
  • Overlay on prototype - Direct visual feedback
  • High resolution - Perfect for presentations

docs.title: Gaze Plots
docs.text:
Follow the eye's journey:

  • Sequential path - Numbered fixation points
  • Saccade lines - See eye movements between fixations
  • Temporal information - Understand viewing order

docs.title: Mouse Trails
docs.text:
Understand interaction patterns:

  • Movement paths - Complete mouse journey

docs.title: 👥 Multi-User Management
docs.text:
Built for teams.

  • User Roles - Admin, researcher, viewer
  • Authentication - Secure login system
  • Session Management - Track who's accessing data

docs.title: 🔒 Privacy & Security
docs.text:
Your data stays yours.

  • Self-Hosted - Complete data control
  • Encrypted Storage - Secure database

docs.title: 🌐 Remote Testing
docs.text:
Test participants anywhere in the world.

  • Share a Link - No installation for participants
  • Cross-Platform - Windows, Mac, Linux
  • Mobile Support - Desktop and laptop tested
  • Asynchronous - Participants complete on their schedule
  • Automatic Storage - Data saved immediately

docs.title: 📊 Study Management
docs.text:
Organize complex research projects.

  • Multiple Studies - Run many studies
  • Study Comparison - Compare results across studies
  • Participant Filtering - Slice data by demographics
  • Export Templates - Standardized data formats
  • Batch Operations - Manage multiple participants

docs.title: Statistical Exports
docs.text:
Ready for serious analysis.

Includes:

  • Participant identifiers
  • Precise timestamps (millisecond accuracy)
  • Screen coordinates

docs.title: Reproducible Methodology
docs.text:
Science-ready research.

  • Version Control - Track configuration changes
  • Standardized Calibration - Consistent across participants
  • Documented Procedures - Export study protocols

docs.title: Optimized Data Collection
docs.text:
Fast and efficient.

  • Efficient Storage - Compressed data formats
  • Background Processing - No lag for participants
  • Automatic Cleanup - Manage storage automatically

docs.title: Scalability
docs.text:
From small pilots to large studies.

  • Large Datasets - Handle thousands of participants
  • Export Streaming - Handle huge files efficiently

docs.title: Browsers
docs.text:
✅ Fully Tested and Supported: - Chrome 90+

⚠️ Partial Support: - Firefox 88+ - Edge 90+

What happens if something fails?

When no webcam is detected by the browser it won't allow the user to conduct the study. Preventing the introduction of noise in the study.

docs.title: Operating Systems
docs.text:
✅ Fully Supported:

  • Windows 10/11
  • Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Debian, Arch)

docs.title: Devices
docs.text:
✅ Recommended:

  • Desktop computers
  • Laptops with webcams

❌ Not Supported: - Smartphones (screen too small) - Tablets

docs.title: UX Research
docs.text:
• Usability Testing - Find interface problems
  • Information Architecture - Validate navigation
  • Visual Hierarchy - Test design priorities
  • A/B Testing - Compare design variants

docs.title: Marketing
docs.text:
• Landing Page Optimization - What catches attention?
  • Ad Testing - Evaluate visual campaigns
  • Email Design - Test newsletter layouts
  • Banner Design - Optimize visual ads

docs.title: Academic Research
docs.text:
• HCI Studies - Human-computer interaction research
  • Visual Perception - Study visual attention
  • Reading Patterns - Text and layout research
  • User Behavior - Interaction pattern analysis

docs.title: Product Development
docs.text:
• Feature Discovery - Are features findable?
  • Onboarding - Test first-time user experience
  • Prototype Testing - Validate before development
  • Competitive Analysis - Study competitor interfaces

Ready to explore specific features? Choose a topic:

  • 🏠 Participant Registration
  • 👁️ Eye Tracking Process
  • 👥 Managing Participants

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text:
Your First Eye-Tracking Study in 5 Minutes

Follow this guide to run your first study from start to finish. By the end, you'll have collected real eye-tracking data!

docs.title: 🎯 What You'll Accomplish
docs.text:
In this quick start, you'll:

  1. ✅ Set up a simple eye-tracking study
  2. ✅ Test it yourself as a participant
  3. ✅ View beautiful heatmap visualizations
  4. ✅ Export your data

Let's go! 🚀

docs.title: Step 1: Launch RemoteGazeUX
docs.text:
Open your terminal and start the application:

cd RemoteGazeUX
python run.py

After being asked to modify your configuration, create admin users you should see:

✨ RemoteGazeUX is running!
🔗 URL: https://localhost:5001

Keep this terminal window open

The application runs here. You'll see helpful logs as participants connect.

docs.title: Use the Configuration GUI
docs.text:
When running RemoteGazeUX you should see

Do you want to modify configurations before running the application? (y/n):

Inputting yes will open a GUI for setting a new prototype URL, a different port or also change the tasks.

Also, you can open this GUI with:

python src/config.py

A friendly GUI window appears! 🎨

TODO: hacer captura

Fill in your study details:

  • Study Name: "My First Eye-Tracking Test"
  • Prototype URL: Use the demo or your own Figma prototype
  • Demo: https://www.figma.com/proto/example (try a real Figma link!)
  • Or upload an image path: /path/to/your/image.png
  • Tasks: Define what participants should do
  • Task 1: "Find the login button"
  • Task 2: "Locate the search feature"

Click Save ✅

docs.title: Step 3: Test as a Participant
docs.text: Now for the fun part — experience what your participants will see!

docs.title: 3.1 Open the Study
docs.text: Navigate to: http://localhost:5000

docs.title: 3.2 Fill the Entry Form
docs.text:
You'll see a clean registration form:

Fill in test data:

  • Name: Test
  • Surname: User
  • Age: 25

Click Submit 🎯

docs.title: 3.3 Calibration
docs.text:
Calibration is Key

Good calibration = accurate eye-tracking data. Take your time here!

You'll see a series of dots on screen:

  1. Sit comfortably - Keep your head relatively still
  2. Click each dot - Look directly at each point when clicking
  3. Click 5 times per dot when prompted
  4. Follow instructions carefully

Pro Tip

Room lighting matters! Avoid backlighting (windows behind you) for best results.

docs.title: 3.4 Complete the Tasks
docs.text:
After calibration, you'll see your prototype with task instructions:

  • Task instructions appear at the top

Just interact naturally! Look around, click things, explore the interface.

docs.title: 3.5 Finish
docs.text:
When all tasks are complete, you'll see a thank you message.

Congratulations! You've just collected your first eye-tracking data! 🎉

docs.title: Step 4: View Your Results
docs.text: Now for the exciting part — see what you tracked!

docs.title: 4.1 Access the Admin Panel
docs.text:
Navigate to: http://localhost:5000/sujetos

Login with your admin credentials.

docs.title: 4.2 Explore Your Data
docs.text:
You'll see:

  • Studies tab - All your studies
  • Participants list - Click on "Test User"
  • Session details - Timestamp, duration, task completion

docs.title: 4.3 View the Heatmap
docs.text:
Click "View Results" for your test participant.

Wow! 🤯 This heatmap shows:

  • 🔥 Hot spots (red/yellow) - Where you looked most
  • 🧊 Cold spots (blue/green) - Areas you ignored
  • ⚫ Blind spots - Never looked at

docs.title: 4.4 Analyze the Data
docs.text:
Toggle through different visualizations:

  • Static Heatmap - Overall attention distribution
  • Gaze Plot - Sequential path of eye movements
  • Mouse Track - Where you clicked and moved

Publication-Ready Graphics

These visualizations are high-quality and ready for presentations or papers!

docs.title: Step 5: Export Your Data
docs.text: Want to analyze the raw data? Easy!

docs.title: Export Entire Study
docs.text: From the studies page, click "Download All Data" to get all participants data.

docs.title: 🎓 You Did It!
docs.text:
In just 10 minutes, you've:

  • ✅ Set up a study
  • ✅ Collected eye-tracking data
  • ✅ Generated professional visualizations
  • ✅ Exported data for analysis

docs.title: 🚀 Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you know the basics, level up:

Customize Your StudyAnalyze ResultsAdvanced Features

Make it Your Own:

  • Add more tasks
  • Use your own prototypes

Configuration guide →

Deep Dive into Data:

  • Statistical analysis
  • Comparison between participants
  • Task performance metrics
  • Attention mapping

Power User Mode:

  • Multiple simultaneous studies
  • Custom databases
  • API integration
  • Automated reporting

Documentation soon...

docs.title: 💡 Tips for Success
docs.text:
Best Practices

For Accurate Data:

  • Ensure good lighting (avoid backlighting)
  • Ask participants to keep their head relatively still
  • Test your calibration process first

For Better Studies:

  • Keep tasks clear and specific
  • Don't have too many tasks
  • Pilot test with 2-3 people first
  • Provide clear instructions to participants

Common Gotchas

  • Calibration skipped? Data quality suffers. Always calibrate!
  • Poor lighting? Tracking accuracy drops
  • Too many browser tabs? Close them for better performance
  • Mobile devices? Eye-tracking works best on desktop/laptop

docs.title: 🎯 Challenge: Run a Real Study!
docs.text:
Ready for the real deal?

  1. Design a meaningful study - What do you want to learn?
  2. Recruit 5-10 participants - Friends, colleagues, or users
  3. Collect real data - Run your study!
  4. Analyze and share - What did you discover?

Share your results with the community — we'd love to see what you learn! 🌟

Feeling confident? → Learn about all features

Want to go deeper? → Advanced configuration

docs.title: Gaze Tracking Process
docs.text:
The Magic Happens Here

This is where RemoteGazeUX transforms webcam data into insights. Let's explore how it works!

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text:
The eye tracking page is the heart of RemoteGazeUX. It handles:

  1. Webcam initialization 📷
  2. Calibration 🎯
  3. Real-time gaze tracking 👁️
  4. Task presentation 📋
  5. Data collection 💾

All happening seamlessly in the browser!

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text:
┌──────────────────┐
│  Webcam Access   │ ← User grants permission
│   Request        │
└────────┬─────────┘
         │
         ▼
┌──────────────────┐
│  Camera Setup    │ ← WebGazer initializes
│  & Positioning   │
└────────┬─────────┘
         │
         ▼
┌──────────────────┐
│  Calibration     │ ← Click dots to train
│                  │
└────────┬─────────┘
         │
         ▼
┌──────────────────┐
│  Task 1          │ ← Present prototype
│  Execution       │   + Track gaze
└────────┬─────────┘
         │
         ▼
┌──────────────────┐
│  Task 2, 3...    │ ← Continue tasks
│  (Sequential)    │
└────────┬─────────┘
         │
         ▼
┌──────────────────┐
│  Data Saved      │ ← Store in database
│  Thank You!      │
└──────────────────┘

docs.title: What Happens
docs.text:
When participants first arrive, they see a permission request:

"RemoteGazeUX wants to use your camera"

docs.title: 🎯 Step 2: Calibration
docs.text:
Calibration = Accuracy

This is the most critical step! Good calibration means good data.

docs.title: What is Calibration?
docs.text:
Calibration teaches WebGazer where YOU look:

  • Machine Learning: Builds a model unique to each user
  • Click-to-Gaze: Correlates mouse clicks with eye position
  • Continuous: Model improves throughout the session

docs.title: The Calibration Interface
docs.text: Participants see a series of points that must be clicked to calibrate the model.

docs.title: Visual Feedback
docs.text:
Real-time feedback helps participants:

  • ✅ Change in color - Point complete

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Once calibrated, WebGazer continuously:

  1. Captures webcam frames (60 fps)
  2. Detects face and eyes (facial landmarks)
  3. Predicts gaze point (machine learning model)
  4. Records coordinates (x, y on screen)
  5. Stores data (timestamped points)

docs.title: What Participants See
docs.text: They only see the information of tasks. In prior studies conducted by the developers of WebGazer.js it was shown that gaze feedback was a distraction.

docs.title: Simultaneous Collection
docs.text: While tracking gaze, we also record mouse movements

docs.title: Task Display
docs.text: TODO: agregar una captura de como se muestran las tareas.

docs.title: Real-Time Saving
docs.text: Data is saved continuously.

docs.title: For Accurate Tracking
docs.text:
Do's

  • ✅ Calibrate thoroughly - Don't rush
  • ✅ Good lighting - Even, front-facing light
  • ✅ Stable position - Don't move around much
  • ✅ Clear instructions - Participants understand what to do
  • ✅ Pilot test - Test with a few people first

Don'ts

  • ❌ Skip calibration - Data will be poor
  • ❌ Backlit participants - Windows behind them
  • ❌ Moving heads - Accuracy suffers
  • ❌ Too many tasks - Fatigue reduces quality
  • ❌ Long sessions - Keep under 20 minutes

docs.title: For Better Data Quality
docs.text:
1. Instruct participants:

  2. Sit still

  3. Look naturally
  4. Don't overthink

  5. Be honest in responses

  6. Environment setup:

  7. Good lighting

  8. Quiet space
  9. No distractions

  10. Comfortable chair

  11. Task design:

  12. Clear objectives

  13. Reasonable time limits
  14. Not too complex
  15. Natural scenarios

docs.title: WebGazer.js
docs.text:
What is it?

  • Open-source eye tracking library
  • Works entirely in browser
  • No server-side processing

Cited in 1000+ research papers!

docs.title: Browser Requirements
docs.text:
Browser Version Support Chrome 90+ ✅ Full Firefox 88+ ⚠️ Limited Edge 90+ ⚠️ Limited Safari 14+ ❌ Not supported Mobile Any ❌ Not supported

Next Step: Managing Participants →

docs.title: Participant Registration
docs.text:
The Gateway to Your Study

This is the first thing participants see. Make it count!

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text:
The Home Page (accessible at /) is your study's front door. It's where participants:

  1. Learn about the study
  2. Provide demographic information
  3. Begin the tracking session

A well-designed entry page leads to better data quality and higher completion rates!

docs.title: Clean, Professional Interface
docs.text:
First impressions matter. The home page only features:

  • Simple Form - Quick, non-intimidating registration

docs.title: Smart Validation
docs.text:
Prevent bad data before it starts:

  • ✅ Required field checking
  • ✅ Format validation (email, age ranges)
  • ✅ Real-time error messages
  • ✅ Prevent duplicate submissions

docs.title: Step-by-Step Process
docs.text:
1. Landing 🌐
  2. Participant visits the home URL

  3. Sees welcome message

  4. Filling Form ✍️

  5. Enters required information
  6. Sees real-time validation

  7. Corrects any errors

  8. Submit 🚀

  9. Clicks "Submit"
  10. Redirected to calibration page
  11. Study session starts

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text:
┌─────────────────┐
│   Visit Home    │
│   Page (/)      │
└────────┬────────┘
         │
         ▼
┌─────────────────┐
│  Fill Out Form  │
│  (Demographics) │
└────────┬────────┘
         │
         ▼
┌─────────────────┐
│  Submit Form    │
│  Begin Study    │
└────────┬────────┘
         │
         ▼
┌─────────────────┐
│  Redirect to    │
│  Calibration    │
└─────────────────┘

docs.title: Managing Participants
docs.text:
Your Command Center

The Subjects page is where you manage all your participant data and access results. Think of it as your research dashboard!

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text:
The Subjects Management Page (/sujetos) is your central hub for:

  • 📊 Viewing all participants
  • 📈 Accessing individual results
  • 📥 Downloading data

Access: Requires admin login (protected route)

docs.title: Multi-Study Organization
docs.text:
